work.p: This manuscript is reminscent of the following line, from the poem that would eventually be titled "I Sing the Body Electric": "Knowledge becomes him . . . . he likes it always . . . . he brings everything to the test of himself" (1855, p. 80).

titleStmt.title: I subject all the teachings
a machine readable transcription

availability.p: The text of the original item is in the public domain. The text encoding and editorial notes were created and/or prepared by the Walt Whitman Archive and are licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International License (CC BY 4.0). Any reuse of the material should credit the Walt Whitman Archive. Permission to reproduce the graphic images of the original item has been granted by the owners of the original for this publication only.

notesStmt.note: Whitman may have drafted this manuscript in the early 1850s as he was composing the first (1855) edition of Leaves of Grass. He expressed similar sentiments in the fifth poem in that edition, entitled "Leaves of Grass," eventually entitled "I Sing the Body Electric." The manuscript is written on the blank side of an 1850s tax form from the City of Williamsburgh.

lg.l:
To me I subject all the teachings
of the schools, and
all dicta and authority,
to my the tests of myself

And myself,—and I encourage
you to subject the
same to the tests of
yourself—and to
subject me and my
words, severely as any,
to stronger the strongest tests than
any thing else of an
